linkTarget.anchoringText: The initial production rates of gas wells at the Cenomanian deposit were 1-1.5 million m3/day. Presently, due to the decrease in reservoir pressure, the actual average gas production rate for gas wells is 90,000 m3/day (Fig. 1). Among the current operational problems are the low wellhead pressures, as well as water and sand production. A proper understanding of the reasons for uneven drainage of gas volumes and distribution of reservoir pressure is also important for their management in order to efficiently solve the well operation problems.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: The histogram of the gas well production rates for the Cenomanian reservoir at 01/01/2016

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 4 shows a map of the current hydraulic conductivity for gas according to the well test data. Due to the relatively low current rate of GWC movement, a good quality PBU data were used for the period since 2013. Maps of current hydraulic conductivity for gas kef·h according to WLIR-2016 and WLIR-2013 are shown in Fig. 5 a, b. Comparison of Fig. 4 and 5 displays the following trends.

image-wrap.caption: Map of current values of the hydraulic conductivity k·h (mDarcy·m) based on the well test data of GPF-1 and GPF-4

formatted-caption.caption-text: Map of current values of the hydraulic conductivity k·h (mDarcy·m) based on the well test data of GPF-1 and GPF-4

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 4 shows a map of the current hydraulic conductivity for gas according to the well test data. Due to the relatively low current rate of GWC movement, a good quality PBU data were used for the period since 2013. Maps of current hydraulic conductivity for gas kef·h according to WLIR-2016 and WLIR-2013 are shown in Fig. 5 a, b. Comparison of Fig. 4 and 5 displays the following trends.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Maps of kef·h (mDarcy·m) according to WLIR-2016 (a) and WLIR-2013 (b). Red contour line marks the drainage zone of GPF-1

formatted-caption.caption-text: Maps of kef·h (mDarcy·m) according to WLIR-2016 (a) and WLIR-2013 (b). Red contour line marks the drainage zone of GPF-1

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 6 shows a map of the current GWC levels for the analyzed area of the reservoir. In the process of development, gas production from the central (dome) zone predetermined the general elevation of the GWC. Thus, maximum movement of the GWC is associated with the central zone of the GPF-1 and GPF-4 area, which is characterized by the maximum initial gas-saturated thicknesses.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Map of the current (for 2016) GWC levels. Red contour line marks the drainage zone of GPF-1

formatted-caption.caption-text: Map of the current (for 2016) GWC levels. Red contour line marks the drainage zone of GPF-1

linkTarget.anchoringText: In Fig. 7 a, b according to WLIR-2013 and in Fig. 8 a, b according to WLIR-2016 a map of the average permeability values above and below the current (for 2016) GWC is presented. It can be seen on the maps that the local high permeability zones in the center of the dome (near wells 106, 107) are confined to the top part of the reservoir, so that GWC movement didn't influence much the average permeability of these zones in the gas-saturated region. On the periphery, the picture is somewhat different. The rising water occupies the regions within the initial GWC contour and the intervals above the initial GWC. For the gas-saturated part on the periphery, this means the loss of intervals with a relatively high permeability, with their commingling to the water-saturated zone.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Map of average permeability above (a) and below (b) the current level of the GWC (for 2016) according to WLIR-2013

formatted-caption.caption-text: Map of average permeability above (a) and below (b) the current level of the GWC (for 2016) according to WLIR-2013

linkTarget.anchoringText: In Fig. 7 a, b according to WLIR-2013 and in Fig. 8 a, b according to WLIR-2016 a map of the average permeability values above and below the current (for 2016) GWC is presented. It can be seen on the maps that the local high permeability zones in the center of the dome (near wells 106, 107) are confined to the top part of the reservoir, so that GWC movement didn't influence much the average permeability of these zones in the gas-saturated region. On the periphery, the picture is somewhat different. The rising water occupies the regions within the initial GWC contour and the intervals above the initial GWC. For the gas-saturated part on the periphery, this means the loss of intervals with a relatively high permeability, with their commingling to the water-saturated zone.

image-wrap.caption: Map of average effective permeability values above the current GWC (for 2016) according to WLIR-2016 (a) and WLIR-2013 (b)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Map of average effective permeability values above the current GWC (for 2016) according to WLIR-2016 (a) and WLIR-2013 (b)

linkTarget.anchoringText: General configuration of the increased hydraulic conductivity zones according to WLIR-2013 and WLIR-2016 has a similar appearance and is largely controlled by current gas-saturated thicknesses in the dome part of the site (see Fig. 11 below).

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Map of the average rate of pressure increase (atm/day) during the first "quarter" from the well stopping moment within the GPF-1 and GPF-4 zones. The dash line shows the boundaries of the region with the pressure increase data

formatted-caption.caption-text: Map of the average rate of pressure increase (atm/day) during the first "quarter" from the well stopping moment within the GPF-1 and GPF-4 zones. The dash line shows the boundaries of the region with the pressure increase data

linkTarget.anchoringText: A later period of pressure build-up is associated with a general redistribution of gas volumes within the stopped area and between it and the peripheral zones. To assess this effect, Fig. 12 shows a similar map of the rates of pressure increase (also in atm per day) for the third "quarter" from the moment of well stopping.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Map of the average rate of pressure increase (atm/day) in 2 "quarters" from the well stopping moment within the GPF-1 and GPF-4 zones. The dash line shows the boundaries of the region with the pressure increase data

formatted-caption.caption-text: Map of the average rate of pressure increase (atm/day) in 2 "quarters" from the well stopping moment within the GPF-1 and GPF-4 zones. The dash line shows the boundaries of the region with the pressure increase data

linkTarget.anchoringText: The rate of pressure increase over a long period from the well stopping, as shown in Fig. 12, is indirectly interrelated with the inhomogeinity of the GWC advancement (see Fig. 6). Perhaps this fact reflects a greater effect of bottom water on pressure build-up in zones with improved vertical connection of the reservoir. At the same time, correlation with the current gas-saturated thickness (Fig. 13) is not evident.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Map of current gas-saturated thicknesses for 2016 within the GPF-1 and GPF-4 zones. The dash line shows the boundaries of the region with the pressure increase data

formatted-caption.caption-text: Map of current gas-saturated thicknesses for 2016 within the GPF-1 and GPF-4 zones. The dash line shows the boundaries of the region with the pressure increase data

linkTarget.anchoringText: To confirm what has been said, we present the results of flow simulations with a simplified sector model of a typical zone of the deposit. The general view of the model is shown in Fig. 14.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: General view of the sector model. The color shows initial water saturation

formatted-caption.caption-text: General view of the sector model. The color shows initial water saturation

linkTarget.anchoringText: As an example, Fig. 15 shows simulation results of the homogeneous model for two simulation cases that differ by the lateral-to-vertical permeability ratio. The operating modes of well clusters and the dynamics of gas production in the cases are the same. Differences are noticable in the calculated dynamics of water production. Apparently, the vertical permeability fundamentally affects the bottom water inflow dynamics. Moreover, even the minimum value of the lateral-to-vertical permeability of 10 is much higher the average value in the cell columns of the FSM (about 3). At the same time, the calculated rates of bottom water advancement towards gas wells are significantly higher than those observed according to field data. The same tendencies are evident in the simulations on the heterogeneous (stochastic) model.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Dynamics of water production for one of the well clusters. Kx – lateral permeability, Kz – vertical permeability

formatted-caption.caption-text: Dynamics of water production for one of the well clusters. Kx – lateral permeability, Kz – vertical permeability

linkTarget.anchoringText: A joint analysis of the map of current gas-saturated thicknesses (Fig. 13) and the geologo-statistic profile (Fig. 16) made it possible to make a forecast of trends in the future changes of the average permeability within the gas-saturated zone.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Geologo-statistic profile for permeability, the GPF-1 zone

formatted-caption.caption-text: Geologo-statistic profile for permeability, the GPF-1 zone
